results.title: Archaeology in the laboratory
results.creator_credit: J.P. Baux and Service du Film de Recherche
results.brief_description: Presents a study of a cave, the Grotte du Lazaret, near Nice in France. Reveals much about the life of man 130,000 years ago. Includes studies of sedimentation, microscopic slides, isotopes of uranium and oxygen and pollen examinations. Gives a detailed analysis of man’s organization in this cave. Suitable for Lower-Upper Secondary students.

results.title: Respiration in man
results.brief_description: Living tissue and various instruments, techniques and experiments are used to illustrate the structure of the lungs. Movements of alveoli and blood in the vessels, gas concentration relationship, transport of 02 and C02, aortic and carotid bodies, and the function of carotid bodies are also shown. No other credits available.

results.title: Who needs rules?
results.creator_credit: Gregory Heimer and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: This film shows the wide range of rules of society, from everyday rules to the complex rules of law. Gives two examples: two children decide whether or not to keep a stray dog in an apartment prohibiting animals; and a boy involved in a playground row is torn between the school rule against fighting and his father’s order to defend himself. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Only Benjy knows: should he tell?
results.creator_credit: Gary Bergland and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Benjy sees some boys he knows shoplifting. They don’t see him and he doesn’t know whether to tell anyone. Is telling ever justified? This film aims to help students and teachers arrive at some flexible standards for dealing with this troublesome problem.

results.title: Late for dinner: was Dawn right?
results.creator_credit: Gary Bergland and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Dawn, an Afro-American aged around eight, and her two friends have gone to play in the park. Dawn’s mother has told her it is very important she is home on time for dinner and stresses for her not to be late. However on her way home, Dawn collides with a woman running to catch a bus and in the confusion the woman drops a five-dollar bill. The woman boards her bus before Dawn can return the money. Dawn attempts to catch up with the bus but fails and consequently she arrives home late for dinner with money that doesn’t belong to her. Before she can explain, her mother begins to scold her - “Why are you late?” Helps children see that conflicting feelings are both common and normal. Set in the tenament area of Chicago. Part of the “How does it make you feel?” series. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: The Newcomer
results.creator_credit: Abram Murray and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: What happens when a new student comes into the class? The first segment shows David, the newcomer, unsure of himself and lonely in his interaction with his classmates. The second segment replays these scenes to show what might have been done to make David feel welcome. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: Meeting strangers: red light, green light
results.creator_credit: William Brose, Justin M. Purchin and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Child molestation is a serious problem. This film will help the child to understand what to do when meeting potentially dangerous strangers. Examples include adult seeking personal information, driver asking child to help him find the way, stranger offering food or gifts, and a false repairman trying to gain entry into the home. The film does not frighten children or encourage a distrustful attitude toward all strangers. However, the point is made that there are some people who would do them harm and who might be difficult to recognize because they look and sound “nice”. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Mathematics peep show
results.creator_credit: Charles Eames, Ray Eames and IBM
results.brief_description: A collection of five films, each presenting a mathematical idea. The film was part of the exhibition ‘Mathematica: a world of numbers and beyond’. The two minute vignettes use a combination of animation, live action and photographic techniques to present five mathematic principles. They are: ERATOSTHENES; TOPOLOGY: JORDAN’S CURVE THEORY; SYMMETRY; SOMETHING ABOUT FUNCTIONS; 2N: A STORY ABOUT THE POWER OF NUMBER. Drawings by Glen Fleck, music by Elmer Bernstein.

results.title: Solutions to pollution
results.brief_description: An introduction to some possible solutions to air, water, and noise pollution. Stresses conservation of resources, particularly at community level. Could be used to stimulate further in-depth discussion on some of the answers it provides. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Black and white: uptight
results.brief_description: The myths that perpetuate prejudice against black people in society and the subtle ways that hate is learned are explored in this film. The social and economical differences that do exist between blacks and whites are caused by historical identities in education and economic opportunity - and are in some cases even perpetuated by laws. The riots that erupted in the cities throughout the United States forced basic issues of injustice to the surface for all Americans to face. There are no easy ways to solve the problems caused by prejudice, but examples are given of areas in which government, business, and black and white people are working together to wipe out the hatred and misunderstanding between the races. This film acquaints the viewer with the subtle and sometimes unconscious manifestation of prejudice as well as the more obvious. It will also encourage the viewer to look more closely at their own attitudes. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.
